text: The sunlight is just right. The town market is livelier than usual—children selling flowers, vendors’ calls drifting softly with the wind.
I sit on the wooden steps outside the tavern, watching the fountain at the center of the square. The droplets sparkle in the sun as if nothing had ever happened.

Alicia has changed into a light-colored dress, her silver hair simply tied behind her. No armor, no sword. She looks slightly weaker than before, as if she still hasn’t fully recovered from last night.
“A rare morning,” she says with a smile. “I want to try living a normal person’s day for once.”
“Heroes get days off too?” I laugh.
“Sometimes they must.” She sits beside me, looking toward the children in the square. “Otherwise, you forget who you are.”

We head to the bakery near the town entrance. The old shopkeeper freezes for a moment when he sees her, then smiles and presses two sweet rolls into her hands. “Last time you saved my grandson, I never got to thank you.”
“Then I’ll accept it today.” She smiles, then turns and hands one of them to me.
“I didn’t save anyone.”
“But you’re sharing breakfast with me.”
The bread is almost too sweet, yet it carries a long-lost sense of peace. Sunlight glints off her eyelashes. In that moment, she looks less like a warrior and more like a traveler.
“If there were no monsters,” I suddenly ask, “would you want to stay?”
She pauses, fingers brushing the edge of the paper bag. “I’ve thought about that. But I don’t belong here.”
“By ‘here,’ do you mean the town—or the world?”
She falls silent for a moment, then smiles faintly. “Maybe… time itself.”
We step out of the bakery. Wind chimes ring softly as children chase pigeons across the street. She pauses at a flower stall, her gaze resting on a bundle of white hyacinths, before shaking her head.
“I used to like flowers,” she says suddenly. “But later, every time I saw them bloom, I thought… they all live longer than I do.”
“Don’t say that.”
“It’s just the truth.” She smiles gently. “But today, I want to pretend—I’m still alive.”
Her voice is so soft, as if afraid to disturb the tenderness of the moment. I don’t reply. I simply walk beside her.
The bell in the square rings. She looks up at the sky and adjusts her cloak.
“I need to check the barrier at the north gate.”
“Now?”
“Just to confirm something.” Her expression turns serious. “Listen—no matter what happens tonight, don’t leave the house.”
“Why?”
She doesn’t answer. Instead, she gently taps the air in front of my chest. A nearly invisible streak of light flickers like dust in the sun.
“This is my protective charm,” she says with a smile. “It will keep you dreamless for one night.”
She lifts her basket and walks into the crowd. Her silver hair glimmers in the sunlight, gradually disappearing at the far end of the bustling market.
Wind blows from the north, carrying an uneasy chill. The fountain suddenly splashes higher than usual.
I look up. The sky is clear, yet a faint shadow slips between the clouds.
A cold feeling settles in my chest. But in the next moment, children’s laughter and vendors’ calls drown everything out. The sunlight remains gentle.
I let out a long breath, yet I can’t shake the feeling that something is quietly drawing near.
